musician | years_active = 199x-present | label = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]], Shell Point, [[Lonesome Day Records|Lonesome Day]] | website = {{URL|www.larrycordle.com}} | associated_acts = [[Carl Jackson]], [[Jerry Salley]] }} '''Larry Cordle''' (born November 16, 1948) is an American [[country music|country]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer-songwriter .{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/larry-cordle-mn0000124925/biography |title=Artist Biography |author=Linda Seida |publisher=allmusic.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015}} Cordle is most famous for his song "[[Murder on Music Row]]",{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/murder-on-music-row-mw0000625171 |author=William Ruhlmann |title=AllMusic Review |publisher=allmusic.com |accessdate=September 7, 2015 }} which was recorded by [[George Strait]] and [[Alan Jackson]] and received the [[Country Music Association]] Award for Vocal Event of the Year, and CMA nomination for Song of the Year, in 2000.{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/cma-awards/2000.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114055357/http://www.cmt.com/cma-awards/2000.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 14, 2014 |title=CMA Awards, Archive 2000 |publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] |access-date=September 7, 2015}} ==Career== Cordle has written songs for [[Garth Brooks]] ("Alabama Clay" and "Against the Grain", the latter of which was also recorded by [[The Oak Ridge Boys]]), [[Mountain Heart]] ("Bitter Harvest"), [[Ricky Skaggs]] ("Callin' Your Name", "Highway 40 Blues", "[[Heartbreak Hurricane]]"), [[Loretta Lynn]] ("Country In My Genes"), [[George Strait]] ("Hollywood Squares"), [[Trisha Yearwood]] ("Lonesome Dove"), [[Kathy Mattea]] ("Lonesome Standard Time"), [[Diamond Rio]] ("Mama, Don't Forget To Pray For Me") and [[Bradley Walker]] ("When I'm Hurtin'") . Cordle also has a career of his own, with his band Lonesome Standard Time. He founded the band in 1990 with his friend Glen Duncan. He received a Grammy nomination for the group's debut album, self-titled, in 1992. In 2005, Cordle's band played at the Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival. On his album 2007 "Took Up and Put Down", he sings "The First Train Robbery"; a song about the [[Reno Gang]] written from brother William Reno's perspective. The Song was written by Chris Stuart"Gettysburg Bluegrass Festival", ''Strings'', newsletter of the [[Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society]], October 2005. Cordle performed on two bluegrass tribute albums for the British rock band [[the Moody Blues]]: ''[[Moody Bluegrass (musical project)|Moody Bluegrass]]: A Nashville Tribute to the Moody Blues'' (2004), and ''Moody Bluegrass TWO... Much Love'' (2011).{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4247134 |title=Moody Bluegrass: Rocking Through the Hills |publisher=NPR.org |date=December 3, 2004|accessdate=August 25, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://bluegrasstoday.com/moody-bluegrass-two%E2%80%A6much-love/ |title=Moody Bluegrass Two…Much Love |publisher=bluegrasstoday.com |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=August 25, 2015}} Along with friends [[Carl Jackson]] and [[Jerry Salley]], the trio (Cordle, Jackson & Salley) recorded the song "You’re Running Wild" on the [[Louvin Brothers]] tribute on [[Universal South Records]], which features numerous country music stars singing songs made famous by the legendary duo. Entitled ''[[Livin', Lovin', Losin': Songs of the Louvin Brothers]]'', this project won the [[2004 Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album|Country Album of the Year]]. The trio tours across the country and performs the hits they wrote for others. ==Discography== ===Larry Cordle & Lonesome Standard Time=== * ''[[Larry Cordle, Glen Duncan & Lonesome Standard Time]]'', Sugar Hill Records (1992) * ''[[Murder on Music Row]]'', Shell Point Records (2000) * ''[[Songs from the Workbench]]'', Shell Point Records (2003) * ''[[Lonesome Skynyrd Time: A Bluegrass Tribute to Lynyrd Skynyrd]]'', CMH Records (2004) * ''[[All-Star Duets]]'', MightyCord Records (2014) ===Solo=== * ''[[Took Down and Put Up]]'' (2007) * ''[[Pud Marcum's Hangin']]'', MightyCord Records (2011) * ''[[Give Me Jesus]]'', MightyCord Records (2017) * ''[[Tales From East Kentucky]]'' (2018) * ''[[Where the Trees Know My Name]]'', MightyCord Records (2021) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.larrycordle.com Official website] * [{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p33809|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic profile] {{CMA for Song of the Year}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cordle, Larry}} [[Category:American country guitarists]] [[Category:American male guitarists]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American guitarists]] [[Category:20th-century American male musicians]] [[Category:Country musicians from Kentucky]] [[Category:American male singer-songwriters]]
